subject: Membership renewal due today at Young Sietar
body:
Dear Emani Richmond, 
A friendly reminder that your membership at Young Sietar is due for renewal today. 
To renew or update your membership log in to your profile at 
https://www.youngsietar.org/Sys/Profile
 with your email e.richmond@lcwmail.com and password and follow suggested actions on your profile screen. 
Don't know your password? Reset it here 
https://www.youngsietar.org/Sys/ResetPasswordRequest
Yours interculturally

subject: New Look, Same IDI
body:
IDI has a new look, new website, and new features to announce!
 
New Look,
Same IDI
We are incredibly excited to present our new look. This journey has been years in the making, but it is just the beginning. The Intercultural Development Inventory, trusted by more than 10,000 active IDI Qualified Administrators in hundreds of organizations, has not changed. However, this update is the first step in our mission to improve the experience for IDI Qualified Administrators, respondents, and organizations using the IDI.
With that, we are proud to unveil the new, streamlined 
IDI Inventory.com
. The new website includes two long-requested features:
Research and Publications
Review a searchable index of published articles from IDI Qualified Administrators using the IDI.
View the Index
QA Database
Find other QAs and list yourself as available for individuals and organizations to hire for their IDI projects.
Sign Up
What Else is New
Our new branding will appear across all platforms. We will be updating resources, such as PDFs, in the coming months to include the new logo and branding. There are also new IDI videos that discuss 
what the IDI is
, 
how it is used
, and 
a brief overview of the IDC
. Finally, we have added new 
case studies
 that showcase how the IDI has been used in different types of organizations.
What is Staying the Same
The IDI itself will remain unchanged. IDI Reports will also stay the same, but with new branding that features our updated logo on the front cover and new IDC graphic.
Visit us online and stay tuned for more updates to come in the future.
Visit Site
Let’s get social
Follow us on social media to keep in touch.
View email in browser
Copyright (C) 2023 IDI, LLC. All rights reserved.
You are receiving this email because you are listed within the IDI, LLC database as an IDI Qualified Administrator or are attending an upcoming IDI Qualifying Seminar. These are only meant for important updates, so please do not unsubscribe. 
Our mailing address is:
IDI, LLC 2915 Olney Sandy Spring Road Suite D Olney, MD 20832-3503 USA 
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can 
update your preferences
 or 
unsubscribe

subject: Reminder: MtO Monday Live on Facebook
body:
More than Organized Monday Live!
Emani Richmond
 
Quick reminder that I will be live on Facebook on Monday at 1:00pm MT for our weekly MtO Monday video. Click below to watch:
 
Join Me Live!
 
 
 
In case you missed last week's video, you can check it out here:
 
 
Watch Video
 
Have a delightful day!
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Thanks for reading, your comments and feedback are always welcome.
Simply reply to this email and tell me what's on your mind.
Copyright 2021 More than Organized - All rights reserved
 
More than Organized, 819-A 12th St NW, Albuquerque, NM 87102, USA (505) 243-4356

subject: Fw: LCW Follow-Up
body:
Hi Emani
Conner has informed me that you are handling this prospect as well. I wanted to check in with you to see if you have reached out or heard from any of them before I reach back out to them.
At my last contact point with them, I sent the email attached here.  They were meeting with their SLT and we were hoping to check in with them to see if we can figure out a way to support them going forward.
From our last conversations this could look like
audit/assessment (perhaps via SCI)
DEI strategy work (e.g. success metrics, establishing and executing a dei framework- perhaps via sci)
deb
From:
 Deb Munster <d.munster@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Friday, July 14, 2023 4:09 PM
To:
 Jenny Wolfe-National <jwolfe@genesysworks.org>; Sue Enright-Chicago <senright@genesysworks.org>; Conner Williams <c.williams@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Stephanie Latarewicz-National <slatarewicz@genesysworks.org>; Alisa Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: LCW Follow-Up
 
 
Hi Jenny, Sue and Stephanie,
It was a mutual pleasure to speak with you as well.  Thank you for sharing your key takeaways with us.  Collectively "brainstorming" with our partners is energizing for us as well!
Conner is out of office today so I am replying on all our behalf with some feedback. Please feel free to use what you feel is appropriate and discard what you don't.
First, 
your Culture Amp results are fairly strong, so you should feel good about that. If we are able to work with you, we would want to look at it more closely and fully, such as see demographic breakdowns so we can do a proper and holistic analysis.  Based on a very quick and initial view, you have some really positive results such as mission alignment and strong manager feedback which is a great foundation for any organization to start with.  On the other end, you have some opportunities to work on decision making, perceptions of equity and talent development to ensure it's inclusive and transparent.  
The good news is that your SLT presentation does point to these but I would recommend the following to consider:
on slide 3, consider editing or adding objectives that speak to talent advancement and retention in addition to recruitment and onboarding. The talent war is escalating and your investment in current staff should be protected, especially if you want to increase diversity at higher levels.  
consider adding in some high level findings from your culture amp survey to support slide 3 statements.  SLT and board members typically respond to data, particularly when it comes from your employees and can create the sense of urgency to build your case.  eg.:
 48% (less than half) see themselves working at Genesys in 2 yrs
44% feel genesys ensures performance standards are consistently applied
45% feel they have access to learning and development to do job well
while 74% feel they have the opportunity to apply, 65% feel they have equal opportunity to succeed and 45% believe they have good career opportunities
NOTE:  if this is going in front of the board, the SLT may not want negative data displayed but perhaps if you balance with the positive?
slide 4 under "potential initiatives include".  In my experience when you add these options, leaders tend to be attracted to terms and ideas they may be familiar with. My concern would be that they may focus on items that may be off target from your true targets and priorities.   
Another way to position your efforts would be to say something like "potential initiatives will be aligned to: (a) key findings from our employee feedback (b) our existing challenges (c) business growth goals to represent a diversified community etc.   
Then, you can talk to examples if you would like.
slide 5.  I would recommend explicitly calling out executive leadership role in your efforts. Leadership ownership and accountability will be critical to adding credibility, visibility to your pillars efforts.  If you have an ask at this point, clearly identify what is your ask of your SLT.  If not, you can talk to fact that the council will need support of SLT, as a first ask.
We hope this is helpful to you.  Please let me know if you have any questions as you reflect on the above!  
Have a great weekend,
Deb
From:
 Jenny Wolfe-National <jwolfe@genesysworks.org>
Sent:
 Friday, July 14, 2023 2:24 PM
To:
 Sue Enright-Chicago <senright@genesysworks.org>; Conner Williams <c.williams@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Stephanie Latarewicz-National <slatarewicz@genesysworks.org>; Deb Munster <d.munster@lcwmail.com>; Alisa Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: LCW Follow-Up
 
 
Hi Conner, Deb, and Alisa,
 
Thank you all so much for your time this week! We really, really appreciate it.
 
Our biggest takeaway from the call were to:
Set a few key metrics based on what our biggest cliffs are
Ensure we have an understanding of what framework we are driving toward
Include an audit as part of our efforts to help identify cliffs and opportunities
LCW is open to acting as a resource as we start this work so that our request for official resources and budget moving forward are most likely to be approved by our SLT and Board. Our understanding was that you all would be open to doing this on a pro bono basis during this “board approval phase.” If I misunderstood that, please let me know!
 
On the last point, we’ve attached (i) what we plan to share with the Senior Leadership Team on Tuesday and (ii) our 2022 Culture Amp survey results. We’d love to hear any feedback you have. I believe the meeting is on Tuesday, but no worries if that is too tight of a turnaround. We’d be happy to incorporate your feedback ahead of the Board meeting the following week. 
 
For finance, could you track your hours and hourly rate?
 
Thank you and have a great weekend!
Jenny
 
Jenny Wolfe (she/her)
Sr. Director of Institutional Giving
O: (713) 337-0522
C: (224) 628-2868
www.genesysworks.org
 
From:
 Sue Enright-Chicago <senright@genesysworks.org> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, July 12, 2023 9:52 AM
To:
 Conner Williams <c.williams@lcwmail.com>; Jenny Wolfe-National <jwolfe@genesysworks.org>
Cc:
 Stephanie Latarewicz-National <slatarewicz@genesysworks.org>; Deb Munster <d.munster@lcwmail.com>; A. Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: LCW Follow-Up
 
Thank you so much, Conner!  It was a pleasure meeting all of you as well.
 
Sue

. 
Learn why this is important
[Think Security – This email originated from an external source. Be cautious with any links or attachments.]
Hi Jenny and Sue,
 
It was so wonderful meeting with you both yesterday. Thank you for taking the time to speak with us regarding your upcoming Strategic Plan Refresh. We wanted to make sure we provided you with some additional general information about LCW and the work we do, so please, find that information attached here.
 
We truly appreciate the care and effort you and the entire Genesys Works team are putting into this new plan, and so, if you have any questions or concerns along the way, please, do not hesitate to reach out. We are happy to help however we can.
 
Thank you,
 
Conner Williams, ACC, CPCC
(he/him/his)
Consultant
LCW

subject: RE: quick question - virtual/in person / IDI Project and Invoice
body:
Hi Sarah, 
 
I hope you are well! 
 
Thank you for reaching out. This project is currently on hold, but I will reach out to you when we are live again! 
 
 
Kind regards,
 
 
Pippa Hugill
 
RALPH LAUREN 
Global Talent Development Design Lead
People & Development 
 
★
 
 
 
 
From:
 Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, August 9, 2023 7:20 PM
To:
 Hugill, Pippa (EU) <Pippa.Hugill@RalphLauren.com>; Woolen, Ashley (US) <Ashley.Woolen@RalphLauren.com>; Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: quick question - virtual/in person / IDI Project and Invoice
Importance:
 High
 
WARNING:
 This email originated from outside of Ralph Lauren. 
DO NOT CLICK 
on links or attachments unless you know the content to be safe.
Hi Pippa & Ashley,
 
I hope you are doing well! I wanted to follow up on the conversation we had at the end of June. We had talked about doing IDIs for the ELT and Board members (about 20-30 folks in 2 cohorts) as a first step in an inclusion learning journey. I had sent you pricing, and you were going to socialize the plan internally. Happy to answer any questions that have come up along the way!
 
In the meantime, I wanted to introduce you to Emani Richmond, one of our talented consultants, who will be leading this work going forward. I will continue to be involved as a strategic advisor but Emani will take over the day to day. To that end, I was hoping we could arrange a time for the 4 of us to meet in the near future. I know you had talked about launching IDIs this month, and I want to be sure to keep that possibility open! I am out next week, but happy to meet tomorrow or Friday, or you could meet the following week with Emani and I can catch up when I return. Let me know what you prefer in terms of your schedule and we can set something up!
 
Independent of the new work we are considering, we received a notice from your accounts department that a recent invoice we submitted was rejected. Here is the information about the invoice that I have. Can you help me figure out what the issue is?
 
Invoice # 
17240329
SOW # 2022-206
Deliverables: Managing Bias in Hiring and Interviewing Microlearning Modules translations (11 languages per module)
Date Submitted: April 13, 2023 (we changed the address on the invoice and resubmitted it more recently)
 
Thank you so much Pippa and Ashley, looking forward to talking with you soon!
 
Best,
Sarah
 
 
Sarah Nodarse
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW
773.474.9138
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
 
Website | Twitter | Facebook | LinkedIn
View our upcoming events | Sign-up for our newsletter
 
I live and work in Chicago, IL – on the unceded territory of the Pokagon band of Potawatomi. See 
this article
 in the Chicago History Museum Magazine for a native perspective on land acknowledgements and the City of Chicago.

 Hugill, Pippa (EU) <
Pippa.Hugill@RalphLauren.com
>

Kind regards,
 
 
Pippa Hugill
 
RALPH LAUREN

People & Development

Learn why this is important
WARNING:

on links or attachments unless you know the content to be safe.
Hello Pippa and Ashley,
 
I am sure she will reach out to you separately, but in the meantime, I want to let you know that Grace’s last day at LCW is today – I am excited for her next chapter, she has been a great asset to LCW, and I am sad to see her go.  Grace and I have had many in-depth conversations about the work you are planning to do together in our weekly 1:1s, and we’ve had a transition meeting as well where she fully briefed me. We would love to find a time to connect with you next week and share with you the new account management plan. For convenience, here is my calendly link, please feel free to grab a slot:
 
https://calendly.com/s-nodarse/30min
 
In the meantime, do also let me know if you have an update from your Board regarding your pitch of the project.
 
Looking forward to getting to know you and working with you!
 
Thanks,
Sarah
 
 
 
 
-
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sarah Nodarse
(She/Her/Hers)
Principal Consultant, 
LCW

s.nodarse@lcwmai.com
Phone: +1.773.938.4174

Talk to you soon!
Grace

Hello Pippa and Ashley,
 
Please find attached the following two documents, both reflecting our updated project design per our recent conversation:
Mitigation Bias Learning Journey

SOW No. 2023166

Please let me know if it would be helpful to also share an SOW without the 30% discount – or any other changes or requests that come to mind.
 
Have a lovely weekend!
 
Grace

I’ll be shortly sending the updated SOW and Proposal.
 
Thanks,
Grace

subject: Well+Being: Raising a healthy eater and moving faster
body:
Should you let your dog lick your face? 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  
 
 
 
PUBLISHED BY
READ ONLINE
 | 
SIGN UP
 
Expert advice to help you live well every day. 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
 
 
Tara Parker-Pope 
Happy Thursday! Today we’re talking about how to raise a healthy eater, and how running late can help lower your risk for cancer. But before we get to that …
This week’s must-reads:
Do you want to build meaningful connections? 
Here are 
four ways
.
Black widow spider bites really hurt! 
Learn more
 
about the iconic arachnid.
ADVERTISEMENT
 
 
 
 
4,000 steps to better health.
 A new study finds a sweet spot 
for step counts.
Why some dementia patients make art. 
Creativity can increase even 
when the brain is failing.
The science of raising a healthy eater
I grew up in a household of disordered eating, food battles and unhealthy meals. I wanted to do better for my own child.
So I turned to science. Researchers have spent a lot of time observing children’s eating habits and learning how adult behaviors can influence them, for good or bad. It turns out that many of the well-meaning efforts we make as parents to encourage healthful eating can backfire.
After talking with various researchers over the years and writing about what I learned, I acted on it. I filled my house with healthful food and let my child make decisions about what she wanted to eat. We didn’t fight if she didn’t clean her plate, and there were no rewards for eating vegetables (a common food mistake parents make). If she didn’t want to try something, I tried to model good habits by tasting it and eating it enthusiastically. And I didn’t make a big deal out of dessert. Sometimes it was fruit. Sometimes it was a trip to get ice cream.
My child is now an adult. She eats a varied and healthful diet and doesn’t exhibit any of the disordered eating I learned from my mom. I’m happy to have broken this cycle. And it’s the reason I wanted to write this week about the science of raising a healthy eater as part of our special children’s health report.
 
(Carlos Miranda for The Washington Post)
To raise a healthy eater, avoid these 6 common food mistakes
Good eating habits can affect a child’s health for a lifetime. Studies show that health problems like heart disease and diabetes can begin in early childhood.
By Tara Parker-Pope
Read more
 
 
How parents can shape a child’s future with small moments of joy
Feeling safe and supported and able to discuss even difficult subjects will help your kid to flourish, experts say.
By Perri Klass, MD
Read more
 
 
Should teens get their wisdom teeth pulled before troubles start? 
Experts say teeth should be removed when they cause problems. But they debate whether it’s good medicine to extract them preemptively when such issues don't exist.
By Marlene Cimons
Read more
 
 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
Pick up the pace!
There’s some great news this week about how moving just a little faster can lower your risk for cancer.
We’re not talking about formal exercise. This study focused on people who hurried up the stairs, ran to catch a bus or hustled across a mall parking lot. The researchers used activity-tracker data for more than 22,000 men and women, and found that those who moved fast for at least three minutes a day were about 30 percent less likely to die of many types of cancer than people who almost always strolled gently from place to place. And the effect was seen even if none of them otherwise exercised.
To learn more, read the full report from Your Move columnist Gretchen Reynolds.
 
(Getty Images)
Why moving fast 3 minutes a day can lower your cancer risk
People who regularly rushed up stairs or hurried to catch a bus were about 30 percent less likely to die of many types of cancer than people who dawdled.
By Gretchen Reynolds
Read more
 
 
Should you let your dog lick your face?
This week, a reader asks about whether she should allow her dog to lick her face.
I’m a lifelong dog owner, and I learned a few things. The risk of getting sick from a friendly lick are very low, but sometimes those general, flu-like symptoms we experience from time to time might be from close contact with your dog’s mouth.
To learn more, read our latest Ask a Doctor column. Our columnist is Trisha S. Pasricha, a physician at Massachusetts General Hospital and an instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School. And she’s ready to answer your questions! Use our 
Ask a Doctor form
 to submit a question, and we may answer it in a future column.
 
(Chelsea Conrad/The Washington Post; iStock)
Advice
 
Do you let your dog lick your face? It can make you sick.
Experts say you shouldn't let your dog lick your face. Here's what to know about the health risks.
By Trisha Pasricha, MD
Read more
 
 
Please let us know how we are doing. Email me at 
wellbeing@washpost.com
.

subject: Ditching the afternoon coffee
body:
Why you may need to break up with your caffeine fix.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
How late in the day can you drink coffee and still fall asleep at night?
August 10, 2023
 
If you want a good night’s rest, experts suggest you stop drinking caffeine within six to eight hours of your bedtime. So if you typically hit the hay around 10 p.m., you’ll want to plan your last cup of coffee between 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.
 
This is because “it can take six to eight hours for your body to process and eliminate the caffeine you consume in one sitting,” Kristine Dilley, lead outpatient dietitian in nutrition services at the Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center, previously told 
Fortune
.
 
“A good rule of thumb is to avoid caffeine after lunchtime,” says Terry Cralle, registered nurse and representative of the Better Sleep Council. “Consuming caffeine six hours before bedtime can reduce total sleep time by one hour.”
 
Why caffeine keeps you awake
 
Caffeine is a stimulant that can help increase alertness and give you more energy. It takes anywhere from 15 to 45 minutes for caffeine to kick in; however, it takes much longer to leave your system. The half-life for caffeine is roughly four to six hours, which means half of the dosage of caffeine is still in your system four to six hours after consumption.
 
However, some people become more sensitive to caffeine as they get older and may need more than eight hours to process caffeine, according to Dr. Marie-Pierre St-Onge, an associate professor of nutritional medicine at Columbia University Irving Medical Center.
  
How do you know if you’ve had too much caffeine? 
 
For most people, it’s safe to consume 400 milligrams of caffeine per day. To put that in perspective, an eight-ounce cup of coffee has about 95–200 milligrams of caffeine, and a 12-ounce of soda has about 35–45 milligrams. But caffeine impacts everyone differently.
 
Some signs of overconsumption of caffeine include:
Restlessness 
Jitters
Insomnia
Upset stomach
Fast heart rate
Dizziness
Anxiety
Dehydration
Dependency 
 
What to do instead of drinking caffeine 
If you’re looking to cut back on caffeine, these tips to can get through your midday slump:
Have a protein-rich breakfast
 
Drink lemon water, decaffeinated herbal tea, or a smoothie
Take a 
30-minute power nap
Take a walk outside
Take a 
cold shower
 
Read L’Oreal Thompson Payton’s full article 
here
.

If you’ve been sitting on an airplane or woken up on the wrong side of your bed, this simple stretch will help relieve tension in your neck.
